channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Fraud Reported as Jobless Claims Reach 38.6 Million
item.description: President Trump, visiting a Michigan factory, again refused to wear a mask in public. Flags were ordered lowered for Memorial Day weekend in memory of those who died from the virus.
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers with the Los Angeles Unified School District provided meals to families in their community at a drive-by grab-and-go on Monday.

item.title: Covid-19 and Nursing Homes: A Striking Racial Divide
item.description: Homes with a significant number of black and Latino residents have been twice as likely to be hit by the coronavirus as those where the population is overwhelmingly white.

item.title: University of California Will End Use of SAT and ACT in Admissions
item.description: The change is expected to accelerate the momentum of American colleges away from the tests, amid concern that they are unfair to poor, black and Hispanic students.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: The University of California, Berkeley, in March. A push to do away with standardized testing has gained momentum in recent years.

item.title: Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
item.description: The actress Lori Loughlin has agreed to plead guilty and to serve two months in prison. Her husband, Mossimo Giannulli, a fashion designer, is expected to serve five months.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:credit: Katherine Taylor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lori Loughlin and her husband, Mossimo Giannulli, leaving federal court in August.

item.title: Hong Kong Stocks Tumble on China Crackdown Worries: Live Business Updates
item.description: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Kong had just been recovering from a monthlong shutdown due to the coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates
item.description: Amid the pomp and propaganda in Beijing, the virus is weighing on President Xi Jinping’s efforts to restart the Chinese economy. It’s also influencing global policy debates over migrants’ rights.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ng Han Guan
item.media:description: Chinese leaders and delegates at the opening session of National People’s Congress in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: As Tara Reade’s Expert Witness Credentials Are Questioned, So Are Verdicts
item.description: Defense lawyers are reviewing cases in which Ms. Reade, the former Senate aide who has accused Joe Biden of sexual assault, gave expert testimony on domestic violence.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Jim Rutenberg and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tara Reade, who has accused Joseph R. Biden Jr. of sexual assault, served as an expert witness in domestic violence cases for nearly a decade.

item.title: I’ve Been Sounding Taps Since My Ship Was Attacked in 1945
item.description: I played Taps for my fallen brothers-in-arms after a kamikaze pilot attacked our ship during World War II. I now play it every year on Memorial Day.
item.dc:creator: Jake Nevins
item.media:description: George Sherwood at the Sampson Naval Training Base in Lake Seneca, N.Y., in June 1944.

item.title: Supreme Court Won’t Block Surgery for Transgender Inmate
item.description: The prisoner, Adree Edmo, said Idaho’s failure to provide the procedure violated the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The decision by the Supreme Court let stand a ruling from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

item.title: Your Advice for the Class of 2020
item.description: We asked On Politics readers — alumni and new graduates — for guidance on navigating our politics.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Prominent Scientists Denounce End to Coronavirus Grant
item.description: A group of 77 Nobel laureates wants the U.S. government to review a grant cancellation for research in China directly related to preventing pandemics.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: The funding provided by the National Institutes of Health supported researchers in China working with bats, which can carry viruses like the one that causes Covid-19.

item.title: Pompeo Quietly Visits Conservative Donors and Political Figures on State Dept. Trips
item.description: The meetings, often kept off his public schedule, have taken place as Mike Pompeo nurtures plans for a presidential bid in 2024 and as he considered a run for the Senate from Kansas.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has chosen not to disclose potentially politically motivated meetings while on taxpayer-funded trips.

item.title: Man Who Filmed Ahmaud Arbery’s Death Is Charged With Murder
item.description: The Georgia Bureau of Investigation arrested the man, William Bryan, who had recorded the fatal encounter in February.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers on Thursday surrounded the house of William Bryan, who had filmed the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: ‘Expect More’: Climate Change Raises Risk of Dam Failures
item.description: Engineers say most dams in the United States, designed decades ago, are unsuited to a warmer world and stronger storms.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: What’s left of the Sanford Lake Dam and spillway on Thursday on the Tittabawassee River in Michigan.

item.title: F.B.I. Opens Investigation Into Fatal Police Shooting of a Black Woman in Kentucky
item.description: Breonna Taylor was killed during a police drug raid at her home in Louisville.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Family of Breonna Taylor, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Breonna Taylor, 26, was killed on March 13 during narcotics raid on her home.

item.title: Ronald Shurer II, Cited for Bravery in Afghanistan, Dies at 41
item.description: An Army medic, Staff Sergeant Shurer charged into heavy gunfire, saving fellow soldiers. He was awarded the Medal of Honor.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Staff Sgt. Ronald Shurer II at a White House ceremony in 2018, when his Silver Star was upgraded to the Medal of Honor.

item.title: $1.2 Billion From U.S. to Drugmaker to Pursue Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: The Trump administration announced a grant to AstraZeneca, which has licensed a potential vaccine that is in trials by Oxford University.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: Scientists at Oxford University are proceeding on an accelerated timetable for a potential coronavirus vaccine in Britain, in partnership with AstraZeneca.

item.title: A Campaign Milestone: ‘I Was Drugged and Raped,’ Heard in a Candidate’s Ad
item.description: A Democratic congressional candidate in Virginia is releasing a TV spot where she speaks candidly about assault, a new step in a political landscape altered by the #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Giovanni Russonello
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Claire Russo, a Democrat running for Congress in Virginia, references her sexual assault in 2004 in an ad for her campaign.

item.title: What Flying This Summer Will Look Like
item.description: New security and health policies at airports and on planes will make traveling this summer a bit stranger and, officials hope, safer.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Airports, like Kennedy International in New York, are largely empty. But travel is expected to pick up a bit during the summer, starting this holiday weekend.

item.title: Sally Rowley, Jewelry Maker and Freedom Rider, Dies at 88
item.description: She fought for civil rights, learned to fly and sold her art on the streets of San Francisco. She died of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

item.title: Trump’s Inaccurate Claims on Hydroxychloroquine
item.description: The president falsely described scientific research around the malaria drug, falsely denied the existence of a federal warning against it and argued, with no evidence, that large numbers of health care workers were taking it.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: President Trump told reporters this week that he was taking hydroxychloroquine.

item.title: As Trump Rails Against Voting by Mail, States Open the Door for It
item.description: Despite the president’s opposition, states are increasingly reducing barriers to what many see as the safest way to vote amid the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:description: Absentee ballots were used for local elections in Garden City, Mich., this month.

item.title: New Threat to New York City: Commercial Rent Payments Plummet
item.description: One landlord reported that 80 percent of retail tenants missed rent. The drop in commercial rent payments could imperil property tax collections that pay for city services.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.category: Real Estate Board of New York
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Many New York City landlords are worried about paying their tax bills as residential and commercial tenants fall behind in their rent.

item.title: Senate Approves John Ratcliffe for Top Intelligence Job in Sharply Split Vote
item.description: The congressman from Texas was confirmed by a divided Senate to take over an office at the center of the Trump administration’s investigations of Obama administration officials.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Questions about Representative John Ratcliffe’s preparedness and suitability for the job are likely to follow him into office, particularly among Democrats and career intelligence officials.

item.title: Justice Dept. Unit That Prosecuted Roger Stone Is Reorganized
item.description: The overhaul of a division of the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington came at the end of a brief tenure by a longtime adviser to Attorney General William P. Barr.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr oversaw the decision to drop charges against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser.

item.title: Scientists Predict ‘Busy’ Atlantic Hurricane Season Amid Virus Crisis
item.description: This year’s season is complicated by the coronavirus pandemic, which makes relief strategies like group shelters risky.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz and Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: Hurricane Dorian approached Ormond Beach, Fla., on Sept. 3.

item.title: 3 Injured in Mall Shooting in Arizona, Officials Say
item.description: The gunfire erupted at the Westgate Entertainment District, an outdoor shopping center that had recently reopened, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Jarod Opperman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Westgate Entertainment District in Glendale, Ariz., where three people were injured in a shooting on Wednesday night.

item.title: Trump to Withdraw U.S. From ‘Open Skies’ Treaty
item.description: The president held out the possibility of negotiations with the Russians that could save American participation in the accord. But even some of his own aides said success for that seemed unlikely.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump’s decision may be viewed as more evidence that he is preparing to exit the one major arms treaty remaining with Russia: New START, which limits the number of deployed nuclear missiles.

item.title: Corpus Christi Shooting: Texas Naval Base Attack Was 'Terrorism Based'
item.description: The gunman was killed, and a member of the base’s security force was injured in the attack at an entrance to Naval Air Station Corpus Christi, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer, Michael Levenson and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Annie Rice/Corpus Christi Caller-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Naval Air Station Corpus Christi was placed “in a lockdown status,” the Texas base said on Thursday morning.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: When Will Your County Reopen?
item.description: Thursday: Meet Shawn Hubler, a longtime California journalist who’s based in Sacramento. Also: The reopening of the state picks up speed.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Lucas Brown washed the dining patio of the Aioli Bodega Espanola restaurant in preparation for its reopening in Sacramento.

item.title: These Labs Rushed to Test for Coronavirus. They Had Few Takers.
item.description: The fragmented U.S. health care system has hampered efforts to expand coronavirus testing, by making it difficult for hospitals to switch to new labs with ample capacity.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: James Tensuan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fyodor Urnov, a scientist at the University of California, Berkeley, oversaw a massive effort to begin testing for the coronavirus, but then found that many hospitals didn’t want the tests.

item.title: On Politics: Putting a Stamp (or Not) on Vote-by-Mail
item.description: President Trump makes false claims, and Mike Pompeo faces scrutiny: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: How the Pandemic Splintered the Appalachian Trail
item.description: The coronavirus scuttled plans and forced officials to ask people to get out of the woods. Of the thousands who hoped to hike the trail this year, only a few hundred remain.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Inaction That Cost Lives
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Coronavirus and Beaches: Can I Safely Enjoy the Sun, Surf and Sand?
item.description: As states reopen, experts say socially distant outdoor activities, like swimming or running along the shore, are some of the safer ways to re-engage with the world. Here, tips for how to enjoy the beach now.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sloss
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Denise Cathey/The Brownsville Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The beaches on South Padre Island in Texas were re-opened May 1.

item.title: Bethenny Frankel’s Dark Journey to Find Medical Masks
item.description: New York officials tapped the reality television star to find masks for medical workers. She found a global bazaar of ex-cons and exaggerations.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Joe Carrotta for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bethenny Frankel at home in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

item.title: G.O.P. Officials Quietly Consider Paring Back Convention
item.description: President Trump has insisted that the Republican convention is moving ahead for August despite the coronavirus. But even he has expressed openness to a scaled-down event.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at the 2016 Republican National Convention in Cleveland. This year, he had hoped for a celebration of his uncontested nomination.

item.title: For Spy Agencies, Briefing Trump Is a Test of Holding His Attention
item.description: President Trump’s intelligence briefings have gotten renewed attention since he blamed them for failing to sound the alarm early on about the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Briefing President Trump has presented a challenge for intelligence agencies, whom he has disparaged as part of a “deep state.”
